answers.author: Robert Carty
answers.text:
I suppose it depends on what information you're trying to get to them. If it's general 'what's happening' messages, you could partner with the utility company to send out a postcard sized update with their utility bill.  
If it's critical around something like infrastructure impacts on their street, old-fashioned door-hangers are an option, and mailing may be necessary. Otherwise having material at the library or distributed to schools for children to bring home are options to consider.  
Sometimes communities can take advantage of neighborhood watch meetings to have  short  critical updates. One thing that drives residents away is when their time isn't respected (and we let certain residents take over a meeting with their single-issue concern). It's good to keep an inventory of non-digital techniques for when there are major power outages caused by severe storms. Sometimes those can last for days. 
Also consider public service announcement or getting on the calendar for a morning chat show on the radio. Still digital, but more traditional. 
One thing we need to ask is, "where do they hang out...where are they?" And go there with whatever materials or options make sense.

author: Judith Heller
text: How do you engage and inform your "non-digital" citizens?  They may be senior citizens without computers or a desire to use them. Or they may be computer-savvy people who simply don't subscribe to email, facebook or visit your website for information.  Providing our citizens with all the information in the world doesn't help if they can't (or won't) receive it.  Sending out printed newsletters becomes costly & time consuming, and it doesn't get citizens the "latest" info.
title: Engaging Non-Digital Citizens
